>	<snip/>
>	It uses its own TestRunner.
>	<snip/>
>	The runner itself uses AssertionFailedError, Test, TestListener,
>	TestResult and TestSuite.  Ant's <formatter>s are extensions of
>	TestListener.  So I'd say Ant uses quite a bit of the framework.
>	<snip>
>	Ant even has a specialized TestCase implementation for tests that want
>	to invoke Ant targets as part of the tests (like most Ant's own tests
>	do).
>
>	I'd rather say it shows the flexibility of the JUnit framework than
>	call it a shame.

I apologize in advance if this seems contentious & I am not meaning to be
rude -- recall, junit rocks -- but this is an honest question/statement
trying to figure out the balance of framework verses user benefit. (User in
this case being ant or Eclipse or...)

What I consider a shame is the amount of stuff used in order to "leverage
the framework". I'm sorry, but it seems to me that there is little or no use
of the framework, ant has effectively re-written it. Sure, it is nice that a
framework can have extension points, but it seems a shame to need to
leverage so many. It seems (from reading this) that ant leverages the
testcase class "assert" helper methods & little else.

BTW: I use the BuildFileTest class to test my ant tasks/scripts. Very nice,
thank you ant. :-) That said, I have a problem when running them inside
Eclipse 'cos they (I believe) use  paths relative to the project they are
in. The Eclipse test collector finds tests in dependent projects, but then
runs them in this projects context, so the tests break not finding the ant
scripts. Any thoughts on how I solve this, or if there are one or two bugs I
ought report? You just seem a good person to ask both question to & this
seems as good a place/context as any. Thanks in advance. :-)

regards

Adam
